PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 364, 314]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|> May/June 2018 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 320, 905, 335]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|> Candidates answer on the Question Paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 584, 375]]<|/det|> Additional Materials: As listed in the Confidential Instructions. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|> ## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|> Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|> DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 273, 516]]<|/det|> Answer both questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 780, 532]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of one hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 531, 905, 560]]<|/det|> You are expected to record all your observations as soon as these observations are made, and to plan the presentation of the records so that it is not necessary to make a fair copy of them. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 740, 574]]<|/det|> You are reminded of the need for good English and clear presentation in your answers. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 585, 358, 600]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 599, 767, 615]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 624, 806, 641]]<|/det|> Additional answer paper and graph paper should be used only if it becomes necessary to do so. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 604, 666]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 666, 759, 681]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 702, 905, 850]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use
1
2
Total

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 739, 89]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 682, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of a rolling sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 611, 151]]<|/det|>
Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 164, 702, 181]]<|/det|>
The top end of the track is a distance \(d\) above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 180, 655, 198]]<|/det|>
The initial value of \(d\) should be approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 212, 881, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 405, 201, 422]]<|/det|>
Blu-Tack

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 880, 660]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 677, 532, 695]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 708, 218, 726]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 708, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the distance between the bottom of the track and the target wooden strip is \(50.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 218, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Place the sphere on the track and hold it gently against the tape, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 838, 237]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 259, 534, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 288, 201, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 288, 848, 307]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the height \(h\) of the top of the sphere above the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 319, 920, 338]]<|/det|>
<form>\(h =\)  ..................................  .................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 350, 180, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 350, 401, 368]]<|/det|>
• Release the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 381, 871, 400]]<|/det|>
• Measure and record the time \(t\) from release for the sphere to reach the target.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[559, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<form>\(t =\)  .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 922, 104]]<|/det|>
Change \(d\) and repeat **(a)** until you have six sets of values of \(h\) and \(t\). Do not use values of \(d\) greater than \(10 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 856, 121]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the distance from the bottom of the track to the target is always \(\mathbf{50.0cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 128, 688, 153]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\frac{1}{t^2}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 583, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 612, 143, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 610, 186, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 609, 648, 636]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{t^2}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(h\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 181, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 457, 662]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 644, 920, 662]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 645, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate stationary wave patterns.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 685, 152]]<|/det|>
You are provided with two pieces of string of different diameters.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 640, 168]]<|/det|>
Each piece of string has a \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass attached to one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 740, 183]]<|/det|>
Using the **thinner** string, assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 198, 816, 615]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 630, 532, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 661, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
The length of string between the hacksaw blade and the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 346, 710]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 768, 920, 787]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... [1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 509, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
When the end of the hacksaw blade is moved a small distance to one side and released, the string vibrates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 556, 728, 575]]<|/det|>
For certain values of \(x\), the string vibrates in stationary wave patterns.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 571, 566, 590]]<|/det|>
